title: 106_hr909
content: The Act titled "Y2K State and Local GAP (Government Assistance Programs) Act of 1999" defines key terms. The Act titled "Y2K State and Local GAP (Government Assistance Programs) Act of 1999" defines welfare programs including TANF, Medicaid, food stamps, WIC, and child support enforcement. The curr_chunk discusses various programs related to child welfare, child support enforcement, and child care, including WIC, child support and paternity establishment program, child welfare programs, and the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of "Y2K compliant" in relation to information technology accurately processing date and time data between the 20th and 21st centuries, including leap year calculations. Grants will be provided to states to ensure state and local government programs are Y2K compliant. The Secretary of Commerce will award grants to States for Y2K compliance in state and local government programs. Priority will be given to Federal welfare programs. Limitations include a maximum of 75 grants and only 2 grants per State. Application deadline is 45 days after enactment. A State Governor's Office may apply for a Y2K compliance grant within 45 days of enactment. The application must include a plan and budget for the program. The State Governor's Office can apply for a Y2K compliance grant within 45 days of enactment, including a proposed budget and funding source. The grant requires a matching expenditure of $1 for every $2 awarded for the program. The grant requires a matching expenditure of $1 for every $2 awarded for the program. The section specifies that the State shall expend $1 for every $2 awarded under the grant to develop and implement a Y2K compliance program. The Secretary of Commerce may waive the matching requirement for states facing undue hardship. State expenditures can be in cash or in kind, including equipment or services. The Secretary of Commerce evaluates grant applications based on feasibility and achieving program purposes. State expenditures for grants must be made after the award, with no credit for pre-award expenses. Grants under this section have a specified length of awards. The Secretary of Commerce evaluates grant applications for feasibility and program purposes. Grants awarded under this section have a maximum duration of 2 years. State funds received through these grants remain available until expended without a fiscal year limitation. Grantees must submit annual reports on the compliance program funded by the grant, with a final report due within 90 days after the grant period. The Secretary of Commerce shall submit a final report to Congress evaluating the programs funded under such grants within 90 days after the termination of all grants awarded under this section. $40,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated for fiscal years 1999 to 2001 to carry out this section, funded from the Y2K Emergency Supplemental Funds appropriated in the FY99 Omnibus Act, PL 105-277.
